item.title: Overall
item.description: Overall NoneType In Python, a value called None represents the absence of a value. The None value is the only value of the NoneType data type. (Other programming languages might call this value null, nil, or undefined). Just like the Boolean True and False values, you must always write None with a capital N. Input

item.title: List Data Type
item.description: List Data Type Syntax Input squares = [x**2 for x in range(10)] print(squares) Output [0, 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81] Input products = [i * j for j in range(3) for i in range(3)] print(products) Output [0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 0, 2, 4] Input

item.title: Dictionary Data Type
item.description: Dictionary Data Type Syntax Input my_cat = {'size': 'fat', 'color': 'gray', 'age': 17} print(my_cat['size']) print('My cat has ' + my_cat['color'] + ' fur.') Output fat My cat has gray fur Input spam = {12345: 'Luggage Combination', 42: 'The Answer'} print(spam[12345]) print(spam[42]) print(spam[0]) Output Luggage Combination The Answer Traceback (most recent call last): File "<python-input-0>", line 1, in <module> KeyError: 0 Returning Values | values() Input

item.title: String Data Type
item.description: String Data Type String is like a list of characters, so is inherits list attributes Escape Characters | \ Input print('Say hi to Bob\'s mother.') Output Say hi to Bob's mother. Raw Strings | r Input

item.title: Tuple Data Type
item.description: Tuple Data Type Syntax Input a, b, c = (10, 20, 30) print(a) print(b) print(c) Output 10 20 30 Multiple data type values Input mixed_tuple = (1, 'hello' , 3.14) print(mixed_tuple) print(type(mixed_tuple[0])) print(type(mixed_tuple[1])) print(type(mixed_tuple[2])) Output

item.title: Set Data Type
item.description: Set Data Type Syntax Input my_set = {1, 2, 3} print(my_set) Output {1, 2, 3} Add Values | add() Data in set cannot be duplicated Input my_set = {1, 2, 3} my_set.add(4) my_set.add(2) print(my_set) Output

item.title: Comparision
item.description: Comparision List and Tuple Type Conversion Input print(tuple(['cat', 'dog', 5])) print(list(('cat', 'dog', 5))) print(list('hello')) Output ('cat', 'dog', 5) ['cat', 'dog', 5] ['h', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o'] Comparing Dictionarie and List Input
